Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: 2D Optoelectronic Graphene Nanoprobes for Neural Network

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1264982 - Xu

The objective of this research is to investigate, across submicron to centimeter size scales, the principle of signal processing from single synapse to multi-neuron circuitry, via a 2D free-standing optoelectronic graphene platform. The approach is to grow neurons directly on a large-area suspended graphene membrane, which is part of an ultra-sensitive graphene transistor in a liquid environment. Through graphene photoconductance measuring, patch-clamp recording, and optical imaging, the electrical, chemical, and optical changes in axons, dendrites and synapses across a neuronal circuit will be investigated.

General statement:
Neuronal activity is typically mapped using electrode arrays that stimulate neuronal cells and record their electrical responses. This system has several limitations: the number of electrodes is typically small and placement of cells in relation to electrodes is not well defined. This proposal will deploy novel material, grapheme, to be used as the surface for culturing neurons. Grapheme has optoelectrical effect, meaning that electrical activity of cells may be monitored optically using a microscope. This would circumvent limitations of electrode arrays and would allow for monitoring activity of a much larger number of neuronal cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this project include development of a new neurotechnology to generate detailed molecular maps of brain activity, and new understanding of complex interactions between graphene and cell membranes. These results provide new insights into electrical activities of individual synapses and neurons in neuronal networks, leading to an in-depth understanding of cognitive behavior and new therapeutic approaches for treating neuronal and psychiatric disorders. Our findings also provide a molecular explanation that reconciles many contradictory reports about graphene’s impact on cellular function. In implementing the research, five graduate students are trained to conduct interdisciplinary research and one of them have successfully completed his Ph.D. program.

The central nervous system is composed of billions of neurons with trillions of dendritic spines and synapses, through which information stores and flows among neurons. It is, therefore, important to understand the relationships between the functional connectivity map of neuronal networks and the physiological or pathological functions of individual synapses and neurons. Recently, graphene has gained significant interests due to its extraordinary electronic and optical properties. In this project, by combining graphene transistors with scanning photocurrent technique, a novel probing system has been developed to investigate the electrical activities of individual synapse and spines with sub-micron spatial and sub-millisecond temporal resolution. This platform has been used to study electrical signal changes in the synaptic contact regions of hippocampal neurons at rest and during depolarization and to demonstrate the ability of decoding detailed waveforms of the spontaneous bursts of individual synapses and spines during depolarization.

For biosensing applications, graphene needs to be as close to cell surfaces as possible in order to maximize its utility. This raises a fundamental question: how graphene affects the plasma membrane and related cellular functions. In this project, we find that graphene increases cell membrane cholesterol and potentiates neurotransmitter release for neuron cells. For fibroblasts grown on graphene, we observe a similar increase in cell membrane cholesterol, which promotes the activation of P2Y receptors. In both cases, direct manipulations of cholesterol elucidate that a graphene-induced membrane cholesterol increase is a major reason for the observation potentiation of cell signaling pathways. Our discovery not only identifies membrane cholesterol as a mediator of graphene’s cellular effects but also provides new prospects for graphene’s bioapplications.

Overall, a new neurotechnology has been developed to investigate the electrical activities of individual synapses and neurons with high spatiotemporal resolution. The obtained insights provide new knowledge about cognitive behavior and new therapeutic approaches for treating neuronal and psychiatric disorders. Moreover, the fundamental understanding of graphene-membrane interactions offers critical guidelines to the design of graphene-based bioapplications.
